moxie

Interface MoxieControl


  • public interface MoxieControl
    Primary point of interaction between Moxie and test classes.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Object[] autoMock(Object... testComponents)
      On the given object(s), automatically populate fields according to the following rules: For all fields having the Mock annotation, populate that field with a new mock object. For all fields having the Spy annotation, create a spy object that wraps the object in that field, and overwrite the field's current value with that spy object. For all fields of type Group, populate that field with a new Group, optionally using the options in any GroupOptions annotation that may be found on that field. For all fields having the AutoMock annotation, also apply these rules to fields on that object.
      void autoUnMock(Object... testComponents)
      Restores fields on the given objects to their values before the objects were auto-mocked.
      LambdaCheck<Object> check()
      Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed, as specified using Java 8 lambda syntax.
      ClassCheck check(Class clazz)
      Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed on a static method or constructor of a class after use.
      <T> ObjectCheck<T> check(T mockObject)
      Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed against a mock after use.
      <R> LambdaCheck<R> check(ThrowingSupplier<R> lambda)
      Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed, as specified using Java 8 lambda syntax.
      void checkNoActiveMocks()
      Raises an error if any mock/spy objects are still active.
      void checkNothingElseHappened(Object... mockObjects)
      Verify that no calls other than those matched by previous checks occurred on the given mock(s).
      void checkNothingElseUnexpectedHappened(Object... mockObjects)
      Verify that no calls other than those matched by previous expectations or checks occurred on the given mock(s).
      LambdaCheck<Void> checkVoid(ThrowingRunnable lambda)
      Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed, as specified using Java 8 lambda syntax.
      void deactivate(Object... mockObjects)
      Deactivate the given mock/spy objects without verifying expectations.

      • mock

        <T> T mock(Class<T> clazz,
           Object... constructorArgs)
        Creates a mock object of the given type, calling a constructor with the given arguments to instantiate the mock. This method is provided for partial mocking of objects that use constructor dependency injection, and to ease portability of legacy JMock 1/EasyMock tests.

        You don't need to call this method if you are mocking a concrete class without a no-arg constructor. By default Moxie uses the Objenesis library to instantiate mocks - this uses JVM black magic to create objects without calling their constructors. Moxie will revert to using constructors if Objenesis isn't on the classpath.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the class or interface that the mock should extend/implement
        Parameters:
        clazz - the class that the mock should extend
        constructorArgs - values to be passed to the constructor
        Returns:
        a new mock object

      • mock

        <T> T mock(Class<T> clazz,
           Class[] constructorArgTypes,
           Object[] constructorArgs)
        Creates a mock object of the given type, calling a constructor with the given arguments to instantiate the mock. This method is provided for partial mocking of objects that use constructor dependency injection, and to ease portability of legacy JMock 1/EasyMock tests.

        You don't need to call this method if you are mocking a concrete class without a no-arg constructor. By default Moxie uses the Objenesis library to instantiate mocks - this uses JVM black magic to create objects without calling their constructors. Moxie will revert to using constructors if Objenesis isn't on the classpath.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the class or interface that the mock should extend/implement
        Parameters:
        clazz - the class that the mock should extend
        constructorArgTypes - the parameter signature of the constructor to be used
        constructorArgs - values to be passed to the constructor
        Returns:
        a new mock object

           String name,
           Object[] constructorArgs)

        You don't need to call this method if you are mocking a concrete class without a no-arg constructor. By default Moxie uses the Objenesis library to instantiate mocks - this uses JVM black magic to create objects without calling their constructors. Moxie will revert to using constructors if Objenesis isn't on the classpath.

           String name,
           Class[] constructorArgTypes,
           Object[] constructorArgs)
        Creates a mock object of the given type, calling a constructor with the given arguments to instantiate the mock. This method is provided for partial mocking of objects that use constructor dependency injection, and to ease portability of legacy JMock 1/EasyMock tests.

        You don't need to call this method if you are mocking a concrete class without a no-arg constructor. By default Moxie uses the Objenesis library to instantiate mocks - this uses JVM black magic to create objects without calling their constructors. Moxie will revert to using constructors if Objenesis isn't on the classpath.

        Type Parameters:

        name - the name of the mock object - will be used in error messages
        constructorArgTypes - the parameter signature of the constructor to be used
        constructorArgs - values to be passed to the constructor

        <T> T mock(Class<T> clazz,
           Object[] constructorArgs,
           MoxieOptions... options)
        Creates a mock object of the given type, calling a constructor with the given arguments to instantiate the mock. This method is provided for partial mocking of objects that use constructor dependency injection, and to ease portability of legacy JMock 1/EasyMock tests.

        You don't need to call this method if you are mocking a concrete class without a no-arg constructor. By default Moxie uses the Objenesis library to instantiate mocks - this uses JVM black magic to create objects without calling their constructors. Moxie will revert to using constructors if Objenesis isn't on the classpath.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the class or interface that the mock should extend/implement
        Parameters:
        clazz - the class that the mock should extend
        constructorArgs - values to be passed to the constructor
        options - one or more MoxieOptions that should apply to the mock
        Returns:
        a new mock object

      • spy

        <T> T spy(T realObject,
          MoxieOptions... options)
        Creates a spy object, i.e. a proxy which wraps an actual object on which expectations can be set and checks can be performed.
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of the object to be spied upon
        Parameters:
        realObject - the object the spy should wrap
        options - one or more MoxieOptions that should apply to the spy
        Returns:
        a new spy object

      • spy

        <T> T spy(T realObject,
          String name,
          MoxieOptions... options)
        Creates a spy object, i.e. a proxy which wraps an actual object on which expectations can be set and checks can be performed.
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of the object to be spied upon
        Parameters:
        realObject - the object the spy should wrap
        name - the name of the spy object - will be used in error messages
        options - one or more MoxieOptions that should apply to the spy
        Returns:
        a new spy object

      • group

        Group group(MoxieOptions... options)
        Creates a new Group to represent a group of calls to be tracked across mocks.

        The returned object can then be passed to Expectation.inGroup() or Check.inGroup() to associate expectations/checks with the group.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Group interface for more details.

        Parameters:
        options - MoxieOptions which should apply to the group (currently either MoxieOptions.ORDERED or MoxieOptions.UNORDERED)
        Returns:
        a new Group

      • group

        Group group(String name,
            MoxieOptions... options)
        Creates a new Group to represent a group of calls to be tracked across mocks.

        The returned object can then be passed to Expectation.inGroup() or Check.inGroup() to associate expectations/checks with the group.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Group interface for more details.

        Parameters:
        name - the name of the group - will be used in error messages
        options - MoxieOptions which should apply to the group (currently either MoxieOptions.ORDERED or MoxieOptions.UNORDERED)
        Returns:
        a new Group

      • expect

        <T> ObjectExpectation<T> expect(T mockObject)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an expectation is set on a mock.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        Type Parameters:
        T - type of the mock or spy object
        Parameters:
        mockObject - the mock or spy object on which the expectation is to be set
        Returns:
        an ObjectExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • expect

        <T> ClassExpectation<T> expect(Class<T> clazz)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an expectation is set on static or constructor methods of a class.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the class on which the expectation is to be set
        Parameters:
        clazz - the class on which the expectation is to be set
        Returns:
        a ClassExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • expect

        <T> ClassExpectation<T> expect(Class<T> clazz,
                               MoxieOptions... options)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an expectation is set on static or constructor methods of a class.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the class on which the expectation is to be set
        Parameters:
        clazz - the class on which the expectation is to be set
        options - MoxieOptions which should apply for the class mock (ignored after the first invocation for any class)
        Returns:
        a ClassExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • expect

        LambdaExpectation<Object> expect()
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an expectation is set using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        Returns:
        a LambdaExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • expectVoid

        LambdaExpectation<Void> expectVoid(ThrowingRunnable lambda)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an expectation is set using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        This method is a synonym for expect().thatVoid(lambda).

        Parameters:
        lambda - a lambda expression invoking the method to be mocked, using parameter matchers as necessary
        Returns:
        a LambdaExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • expect

        <R> LambdaExpectation<R> expect(ThrowingSupplier<R> lambda)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an expectation is set using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        This method is a synonym for expect().that(lambda).

        Type Parameters:
        R - return type of the method/constructor to be mocked
        Parameters:
        lambda - a lambda expression invoking the method to be mocked, using parameter matchers as necessary
        Returns:
        a LambdaExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • stub

        <T> ObjectExpectation<T> stub(T mockObject)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an stub expectation is set on a mock.

        Synonym for expect(mockObject).anyTimes().atAnyTime().

        Type Parameters:
        T - type of the mock or spy object
        Parameters:
        mockObject - the mock or spy object on which the expectation is to be set
        Returns:
        an ObjectExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • stub

        <T> ClassExpectation<T> stub(Class<T> clazz)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which an expectation is set on static or constructor methods of a class.

        Synonym for expect(clazz).anyTimes().atAnyTime().

        Type Parameters:
        T - the class on which the expectation is to be set
        Parameters:
        clazz - the class on which the expectation is to be set
        Returns:
        a ClassExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to expect

      • stub

        LambdaExpectation<Object> stub()
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a stub expectation is set using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        This method is a synonym for expect().anyTimes().atAnyTime().

        Returns:
        a LambdaExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to perform

      • stubVoid

        LambdaExpectation<Void> stubVoid(ThrowingRunnable lambda)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a stub expectation is set using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        This method is a synonym for expect().anyTimes().atAnyTime().thatVoid(lambda).

        Parameters:
        lambda - a lambda expression invoking the method to be stubbed, using parameter matchers as necessary
        Returns:
        a LambdaExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to perform

      • stub

        <R> LambdaExpectation<R> stub(ThrowingSupplier<R> lambda)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a stub expectation is set using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Expectation interface for more details.

        This method is a synonym for expect().anyTimes().atAnyTime().that(lambda).

        Type Parameters:
        R - return type of the method/constructor to be stubbed
        Parameters:
        lambda - a lambda expression invoking the method to be stubbed, using parameter matchers as necessary
        Returns:
        a LambdaExpectation whose methods can be used to give details of what behavior to perform

      • check

        <T> ObjectCheck<T> check(T mockObject)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed against a mock after use.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Check interface for more details.

        Type Parameters:
        T - type of the mock or spy object
        Parameters:
        mockObject - the mock or spy object on which the check is to be performed
        Returns:
        an ObjectCheck whose methods can be used to give details of what should have occurred

      • check

        ClassCheck check(Class clazz)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed on a static method or constructor of a class after use.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Check interface for more details.

        Parameters:
        clazz - the class on which the check is to be performed
        Returns:
        a ClassCheck whose methods can be used to give details of what should have occurred

      • check

        LambdaCheck<Object> check()
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed, as specified using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Check interface for more details.

        Returns:
        a LambdaCheck whose methods can be used to give details of what should have occurred

      • checkVoid

        LambdaCheck<Void> checkVoid(ThrowingRunnable lambda)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed, as specified using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Check interface for more details.

        This method is a synonym for check().thatVoid(lambda).

        Parameters:
        lambda - a lambda expression invoking the method to be checked, using parameter matchers as necessary
        Returns:
        a LambdaCheck whose methods can be used to give details of what should have occurred

      • check

        <R> LambdaCheck<R> check(ThrowingSupplier<R> lambda)
        Domain-specific language method - starts a clause in which a check is performed, as specified using Java 8 lambda syntax.

        See the discussion in the summary javadoc for the Check interface for more details.

        This method is a synonym for check().that(lambda).

        Type Parameters:
        R - return type of the method/constructor to be checked
        Parameters:
        lambda - a lambda expression invoking the method to be checked, using parameter matchers as necessary
        Returns:
        a LambdaCheck whose methods can be used to give details of what should have occurred

      • checkNothingElseHappened

        void checkNothingElseHappened(Object... mockObjects)
        Verify that no calls other than those matched by previous checks occurred on the given mock(s).

        If no parameters are given, this check is performed against all active mock/spy objects.

        Parameters:
        mockObjects - one or more mock/spy objects to be checked

      • checkNothingElseUnexpectedHappened

        void checkNothingElseUnexpectedHappened(Object... mockObjects)
        Verify that no calls other than those matched by previous expectations or checks occurred on the given mock(s).

        If no parameters are given, this check is performed against all active mock/spy objects.

        Parameters:
        mockObjects - one or more mock/spy objects to be checked

      • verify

        void verify(Object... mockObjects)
        Verify expectations on, and then deactivate, the given mock/spy objects.

        After verification, the given mocks/spies will cease to be active; attempts to call methods on them or perform checks against them will raise an error.

        If no parameters are given, verification is performed against all active mock/spy objects.

        Parameters:
        mockObjects - one or more mock/spy objects to be checked

      • verifySoFar

        void verifySoFar(Object... mockObjects)
        Verify expectations on the given mock/spy objects.

        Unlike verify(), the given objects remain active after this method returns.

        If no parameters are given, verification is performed against all active mock/spy objects.

        Parameters:
        mockObjects - one or more mock/spy objects to be checked

      • verifyAndReset

        void verifyAndReset(Object... mockObjects)
        Verify expectations on the given mock/spy objects, then make them forget about any expectations or invocations up to this point.

        If no parameters are given, this is done for all active mock/spy objects.

        Parameters:
        mockObjects - one or more mock/spy objects to be verified and reset

      • verifyAndReset

        void verifyAndReset(Object mockObject,
                    MoxieOptions firstOption,
                    MoxieOptions... otherOptions)
        Verify expectations on the given mock/spy object, make it forget about any expectations or invocations up to this point, and set new options.

        Parameters:
        mockObject - a mock/spy object to be verified and reset
        firstOption - an option that should henceforth apply to the given mock
        otherOptions - zero or more subsequent options that should also apply

      • reset

        void reset(Object... mockObjects)
        Makes the given mock/spy objects forget about any expectations or invocations up to this point.

        Note that this method performs no verification as to whether expectations have been satisfied; for that, use verifyAndReset(java.lang.Object...).

        If no parameters are given, all active mock/spy objects are reset.

        Parameters:
        mockObjects - one or more mock/spy objects to be reset

      • reset

        void reset(Object mockObject,
           MoxieOptions firstOption,
           MoxieOptions... otherOptions)
        Make the given mock/spy object forget about any expectations or invocations up to this point, and set new options.

        Note that this method performs no verification as to whether expectations have been satisfied; for that, use verifyAndReset(java.lang.Object...).

        Parameters:
        mockObject - a mock/spy object to be reset
        firstOption - an option that should henceforth apply to the given mock
        otherOptions - zero or more subsequent options that should also apply

      • deactivate

        void deactivate(Object... mockObjects)
        Deactivate the given mock/spy objects without verifying expectations.

        If no parameters are given, this is done for all active mock/spy objects.

        Parameters:
        mockObjects - one or more mock/spy objects to be deactivated

      • checkNoActiveMocks

        void checkNoActiveMocks()
        Raises an error if any mock/spy objects are still active.

        Useful for troubleshooting possible interactions between tests, and possible test memory leaks due to Moxie holding on to active mocks long past their time.

      • autoMock

        Object[] autoMock(Object... testComponents)
        On the given object(s), automatically populate fields according to the following rules:
        • For all fields having the Mock annotation, populate that field with a new mock object.
        • For all fields having the Spy annotation, create a spy object that wraps the object in that field, and overwrite the field's current value with that spy object.
        • For all fields of type Group, populate that field with a new Group, optionally using the options in any GroupOptions annotation that may be found on that field.
        • For all fields having the AutoMock annotation, also apply these rules to fields on that object.
        Parameters:
        testComponents - one or more objects to be auto-mocked - usually just one test instance
        Returns:
        an array containing all mock/spy objects created by this operation

      • autoUnMock

        void autoUnMock(Object... testComponents)
        Restores fields on the given objects to their values before the objects were auto-mocked.
        Parameters:
        testComponents - one or more objects to be auto-unmocked - usually just one test instance
